grammary.title: Future tenses
grammary.content:
Present Continuous =================================================================== Używamy PC gdy mówimy o sprecyzowanych planach - znamy datę i miejsce, wszystko jest już dopięte na ostatni guzik.
1. I'm seeing Sarah tomorrow. We're having lunch together.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Be going to =================================================================== Używamy "be going to" gdy mówimy że mamy zamiar coś zrobić, decyzja została już podjeta.
1. I'm going to have my hair cut tomorrow. 2. She's going to get the last train home.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Present Continuous VS Be going to =================================================================== Present Continuous wyraża że coś zostało zaplanowane, znamy dokładną datę i godzinę. Be going to wyraża intencję, zamiar że coś zostanie zrobione.
I'm meeting Cathy ( = we've arranged to meet) I'm going to meet Cathy ( = it's my intention, but arrangements may or not have been made)
1. I'm meeting Cathy this evening. I'm going to tell her that it's all over.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Future Continuous =================================================================== 1. Używamy gdy mówimy o przyszłych planach.
I will be going to supermarket later - do you want anything?
------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Czasami gdy chcemy podkreślić że coś się wydarzy bez naszej inicjatywy uzywamy Future Continuous.
I'm seeing Sara tomorrow ( = I arranged it) I'll be seeing Sarah at the party tomorrow ( = it will happen anyway, buy I didn't arrange it)
------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Używamy także gdy chcemy kogoś grzecznie zapytać o zaaranżowanie czegoś (np. spotkania)
Will you be meeting us at the airport?
----------------------------------------------------------------
Future Perfect ===================================================================
WILL + HAVE + III forma (past participle)
Używamy gdy chcemy powiedzieć że coś zostanie zrobione do konkretnej chwili w przyszłości I'LL HAVE finishED this article by Friday, so I'll email it to you then.
Ten czas jest często używany z: BY (by Saturday/March/2030 - najpóźniej do soboty/marca/2030) IN (in two weeks / in two months - w dwa tygodnie, w dwa miesiące)
BY + a time expression = at latest - najpóźniej do IN - in six months / in six months' time
----------------------------------------------------------------
Present simple =================================================================== Używamy PS gdy mówimy o cyklicznie powtarzających sie wydarzeniach w teraźnijszości ale także w przyszłosci. Np o zaplanowanych w grafiku imprezach, odjazdach autobusów itd.
1. The train leaves in five minutes. 2. Our classes start next Tuesday.
Inne sposoby wyrażania planów/ustaleń ===================================================================
be due to + infinitive (ktoś ma coś zrobić) ------------------------------------------------------------------ Używamy gdy mówimy że oczekujemy że ktoś/coś ma coś zrobić
1. My sister is due to arrive at 7.30.
Używamy DUE także gdy mówimy że coś jest spodziewane:
2. The next train is due in five minutes
be about to + infinitive (w najbliżeszj przyszłości) ------------------------------------------------------------------ Używamy gdy coś ma się wydarzyć w najbliższej przyszłości
1. My sister is about to have a baby. 2. We are about to go.
be on the point of + gerund (prawie że już) ------------------------------------------------------------------ Używamy bardziej formalnie, gdy coś jest nieuchronne.
1. It is believed that the chancellor is on the point of resignING
be to + infinitive ------------------------------------------------------------------ Używamy formalnie gdy mówimy o oficialnych planach i ustaleniach
1. It has been announced that the Prime Minister IS TO VISIT Malaysia next month.
be to do sth -> ma coś zrobić is to visit -> ma odwiedzić

grammary.title: It is said that ..., he is thought to ..., etc.
grammary.content:
It is said that ..., he is thought to ..., etc.
1. They say that the company may close. It is said that company may close.
People think that prices will go up. It is thought that prices will go up.
2. People say the man is in 40s. The man is said to be in 40s.
The police bealived he has left the country. He is belived to have left the country.
Używany najczęściej w TV, newsach i raportach. 1. IT IS SAID, BELIVED etc. + THAT + reszta zdania 2. HE, The man etc. (podmiot) + is said, belived, etc + to + infinitive (np. TO BE, TO WORK) (bezokolicznik) LUB Perfect infinitive (np. TO HAVE BEEN).
------------------------------------
Przykłady dla poszczególnych czasów:
Present Simple People believe HE WORKS in Africa. It is believed THAT he works in Africa. He is believed TO WORK in Africa.
Present Continuous They think she IS tryING to write a book. It is thought THAT she is trying to write a book. She is thought TO BE TRYING to write a book.
Simple Past, Past perfect, Present Perfect People think he escaped from prison. It is thought THAT he escaped from prison. He is thought TO HAVE ESCAPED from prison.
Past Continuous, Past Perfect Continuous, Present Perfect Continuous They say she was crying when she was leaving. It is said THAT she was crying when she was leaving. She is said TO HAVE BEEN CRYING when she was leaving.
Passive They claim that she was murdered. She is claimed TO HAVE BEEN MURDERED.
--------------------------------------
Adjectives and adverbs for speculation -------------------------------------------------------------------
BE BOUND TO / BE SURE TO + Infinitive ====================================================================
BOUND i SURE to przymiotniki. Używamy BE BOUND TO / BE SURE TO + bezokolicznik gdy mówimy o czymś że napeno jest prawdą, lub że się wydarzy.
1. He IS BOUND TO / SURE TO BE here in a minute = On jest zobowiązany/pewny że będzie tu za minutę 2. SHE IS SURE TO KNOW. She is an expert on the subject = To jest pewne że ona wie.
BE LIKELY / BE UNLIKELY + Infinitive LUB BE LIKELY / BE UNLIKELY + THAT + clause ===================================================================
LIKELY / UNLIKELY to przymiotniki (nie przysłówki)
1. The doctors say that at his age he IS UNLIKELY TO recover = nie jest prawdopodobny że wyzdrowieje 2. I think IT'S VERY LIKELY THAT the meeting will be over by 6.00 = jest prawdopodobnym 3. IT'S UNLIKELY THAT the government will raise interest rates this year. 4. IT IS NOT LIKELY THAT the government ...
